docs.lead_paragraph: EVERY day, across the country, the letters arrive with the inevitability of taxes and death -- which is just what some recipients think of when they open them. ''Dear friend,'' comes the greeting. ''The enclosed AARP card has never been more valuable to you than it is today.'' Some who get the letter view it with dread or with humor, but since all recipients have just turned 50, they cannot help but see it as a symbol: they have just crossed a Rubicon.
docs.abstract: Profile of AARP focuses on challenges facing organization, including slowing of membership growth rate, loss of its lobbying edge in Congress and, most important, difficulty of appealing to people who are 50 to 65 and still working while remaining relevant to older retirees; intellectual, marketing and lobbying strains caused by this division are expected to grow as proportion of members in younger group increases in coming years; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: State lawmakers outlined the battle lines of their budget wars today, with Assembly Democrats proposing to spend generously on schools and health care and Senate Republicans seeking to spend just as generously on tax cuts. Both houses appear more optimistic than the governor about how much revenue the state will bring in over the next year. Released this morning, the Assembly's spending plan would cost $2.29 billion more than Gov. George E. Pataki's proposed budget of $83.68 billion. Senate Republicans, who released their plan on Monday, are slightly closer to the governor, with a budget package that would cost about $84.1 billion.

headline.main: Assembly Plan Draws Lines For an Albany Budget Fight

docs.abstract: New York State Assembly Democrats propose spending on schools and health care while Senate Republicans want to focus on tax cuts, as battle lines are drawn in upcoming budget wars; Assembly plan is $2.29 billion higher than proposed budget of $83.68 billion released earlier by Gov Pataki; (M)
docs.snippet: State lawmakers outlined the battle lines of their budget wars today, with Assembly Democrats proposing to spend generously on schools and health care and Senate Republicans seeking to spend just as generously on tax cuts. Both houses appear more...
docs.section_name: Health; Education; New York and Region

docs.lead_paragraph: Democrats raised the stakes today in the debate over prescription drug benefits for Medicare recipients, saying they would seek more than twice as much money as President Bush requested for such coverage in the next 10 years. In his budget blueprint last month, Mr. Bush proposed spending a maximum of $153 billion on drug benefits in the coming decade. But Senator Bob Graham of Florida, speaking for many Democrats in both houses of Congress, said today that this amount was ''grossly inadequate.''

headline.main: Democrats Double Bush's Proposal on Prescription Drugs

docs.abstract: Sens Bob Graham and Kent Conrad say Senate Democrats will seek $310 million to $330 billion for Medicare drug benefits, up from $153 billion maximum for next 10 years proposed by Pres Bush; lobbyists for elderly seek higher amount; Democrats on House Budget Committee plan to seek $350 billion; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Democrats raised the stakes today in the debate over prescription drug benefits for Medicare recipients, saying they would seek more than twice as much money as President Bush requested for such coverage in the next 10 years.    In his budget...

docs.lead_paragraph: ANDREW DONG retired three years ago with health, wealth and youth to spare. He was 36, the vice president of a Canadian software company about to go public, when he made up his mind to cash in, buy a motorcycle and travel as much as he could. But even for Mr. Dong, a mathematician turned millionaire, the decision was not easy. What quietly guided him was the death of a close colleague, from melanoma, at the age of 40. ''He was diagnosed too late,'' Mr. Dong said. ''It made me realize that you can go at any time.''

headline.main: When Do You Retire? Here Are 6 Answers

docs.abstract: Six people discuss the timing of their retirement; they are Andrew Dong, software executive, Barbara Rubin, college professor, Charles Griffith, airline pilot, Charles Littel, maintenance chief, Betty-Bruce H Hoover, high school principal, and Harold Goodis, endodontist; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Eight months after taking the reins of Conseco, the big, troubled Indiana insurer, Gary Wendt has finally completed the roster of his management team. Mr. Wendt plans this morning to announce the selection of the last member of the team, his chief financial officer: Charles B. Chokel, who spent 23 years at the Progressive Corporation, a leading auto insurer.
docs.abstract: Conseco chief executive, Gary Wendt, selects Charles B Chokel to be chief financial officer; has named David Gubbay as chief of strategic business development (M)
docs.snippet: Eight months after taking the reins of Conseco, the big, troubled Indiana insurer, Gary Wendt has finally completed the roster of his management team.    Mr. Wendt plans this morning to announce the selection of the last member of the team, his chief...

docs.lead_paragraph: CONGRESS has embarked on a great debate over the future of Social Security and Medicare. In the next few years, politicians, health policy experts, actuaries and lobbyists will dissect scores of proposals of mind-numbing complexity. How should people prepare for the looming changes? The answer, said Marilyn Moon, an economist at the Urban Institute, can be summarized in three words: ''Save like crazy.''
docs.abstract: Proposals in Congress for overhauling Social Security and Medicare make it even more important for workers and retirees to take charge of planning, arranging and financing the benefits they receive in retirement (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Mary Welch did not expect to be fired. On Jan. 3, she received her annual performance review from Computer Associates, the giant software company based in Islandia, N.Y. Ms. Welch, a saleswoman in Chicago, ''exceeds expectations,'' the review said. She got an ''outstanding'' rating for meeting ''commitments made to those within and outside of the department.''

headline.main: Questions on Firings and Severance at Computer Associates

docs.abstract: Fired workers at Computer Associates say company is disguising mass layoff as individual firings of subpar employees to avoid paying severance; labor lawyers say if it lacks documentation for firings, company might also have opened itself to lawsuits that argue that firings were discriminatory; company says firings were routine and that it did nothing wrong; since November, company has fired hundreds of workers around world; it will not disclose how many people have been let go, or whether its overall work force of about 18,000 has grown or shrunk in that time (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The government announced today that the principal Medicare trust fund would not run out of money until 2029, the longest period of solvency ever projected in the history of the program. And officials extended the life of the Social Security trust fund by one year, to 2038. The projected date of insolvency for the Medicare trust fund is four years later than the estimate made by the Clinton administration 12 months ago.

headline.main: Trustees Extend Solvency Estimates for 2 Benefits

docs.abstract: Annual federal report on Social Security and Medicare says principal Medicare trust fund will not be depleted until 2029, longest period of solvency ever projected in history of program; extends life of Social Security trust fund by one year, to 2038; its findings detailed; chart (M)
docs.snippet: The government announced today that the principal Medicare trust fund would not run out of money until 2029, the longest period of solvency ever projected in the history of the program. And officials extended the life of the Social Security trust...

docs.lead_paragraph: GREGG RICE, as he was, had a bushy black beard and a perfect sense of where he stood. A professor of biology at Mercy College in Dobbs Ferry, Mr. Rice had a deep and abiding interest in his field. Living nearby in Hastings, he carved out time to car-pool his young daughters and, at night, stayed fit by playing basketball at the same local high school where his wife, Laura, taught English. Mr. Rice hiked and camped and, to his wife's chagrin, liked country and western music. On vacation, his ability to navigate foreign lands was the stuff of family legend.
docs.abstract: Article, offering Gregg Rice, former biology professor at Mercy College in Dobbs Ferry, NY, as example of early-onset Alzheimer's disease, which afflicts less than 5 percent of Alzheimer's patients; Rice was diagnosed with disease in 1997 at age 53 and, two years later, could no longer participate in support group or perform simple tasks at home; now he needs full time help and can no longer go outside alone; photos (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: THE last thing most people would probably want to do after filing their income tax returns is to pull out those documents and study them. But many financial professionals advise their clients to do just that; they see the tax return as a road map for improving your financial condition in the current year. ''One of my philosophies is: don't do year-end planning at the end of the year; do it all year,'' said Laurence I. Foster, a partner in Richard A. Eisner & Company, a New York-based accounting firm. ''When you get your return, it's the basis for your planning.''

headline.main: Positive Lessons From a Tax Return

docs.abstract: Many financial professionals advise their clients to study their recently filed tax returns in order to learn how to minimize next year's tax bill (M)
